brief_summary.textblock: An organ transplant is frequently the best option and, in some cases, the only option to save the lives of transplant recipients. Receiving an organ from a living donor eliminates the need to wait for a deceased donor, an option that many transplant recipients do not survive. However, donating an organ presents health concerns to the donor as well. This study will use surveys to evaluate the understanding of risk and psychological pressure that living organ donors felt when making the decision to donate. It will also compare participants' answers across geographic, racial and socio-economic backgrounds.

clinical_study.study_design: Observational Model: Case-Only, Time Perspective: Cross-Sectional

primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from 1 week prior to donation and 3 months after donation
primary_outcome.description: Feelings of pressure to donate an organ on a 4-point scale e.g.; "1: No pressure" to "4: A lot of pressure."

primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from 1 week prior to donation and 3 months after donation
primary_outcome.description: Understanding of the donor screening process on a 4-point scale e.g.; "1: No understanding" to "4: Full understanding."

primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from 1 week prior to donation and 3 months after donation
primary_outcome.description: Understanding of medical and psychosocial consequences of organ donation on a 4-point scale e.g.; "1: No understanding" to "4: Full understanding."

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from 1 week prior to donation and 3 months after donation
secondary_outcome.description: Understanding of short-term medical risks of donation answered on a 4-point scale e.g.; "1: No understanding" to "4: Full understanding."

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from 1 week prior to donation and 3 months after donation
secondary_outcome.description: Understanding of long-term medical risks of donation expressed by donors on a scale of 1 to 4 e.g.; "1: No understanding" to "4: Full understanding."

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from 1 week prior to donation and 3 months after donation
secondary_outcome.description: Understanding of psychological risks of donation expressed by donors on a scale of 1 to 4 e.g.; "1: No understanding" to "4: Full understanding."

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from 1 week prior to donation and 3 months after donation
secondary_outcome.description: Understanding that recipients may have variable outcomes as expressed by donors on a scale of 1 to 4 e.g.; "1: No understanding" to "4: Full understanding."

arm_group.description: People who will donate a kidney at the University of Minnesota, Mayo Clinic, or University of Alabama
People who will donate a lung at the Washington University School of Medicine or the University of Southern California

intervention.description: People in this study will donate either a lung or kidney

study_pop.textblock: People who will be donating at kidney at the University of Minnesota, Mayo Clinic, or University of Alabama or people who will be donating a lung at University of Washington Medical School or the University of Southern California

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- living donor of a kidney or lung
Exclusion Criteria:
- unable to give informed consent
